assessment_comment: The crossing was replaced with a clear-span bridge by Canfor with environmental oversight and engineering from DWB Consulting Services Ltd. Partial funding for the project was provided by FWCP through coordination from SERNbc. The structure was well-designed to fit the stream channel, with minimal rock placement in areas likely to be within the natural channel and without constricting flow. In future projects, the use of vegetated riprap is recommended, and vegetation removed from the construction footprint should be reinstalled within the disturbed area.
velocity_notes: Construction footprint has a similar gradient and velocity to upstream and downstream.
constriction_notes: The channel width measured within the construction footprint was larger than those measured upstream and downstream, with recorded widths of 4.6m, 4.4m, and 4.0m. The channel was well constructed.
substrate_notes: The substrate was similar to upstream and downstream, consisting primarily of gravels with some cobbles and riprap boulders placed within the stream to provide velocity breaks and habitat. Fine sediment was present along the edges where the pipes were before construction, which will likely disperse downstream over time. Leaving it in place did not seem unreasonable.
riparian_notes: There appeared to be no planting of riparian vegetation within the construction footprint, and no salvaged material had been replanted elsewhere.
flow_depth_notes: Flow depths were shallow, primarily ranging from 2–25cm. Additional placement of larger rock with stone lines could create deeper sections; however, this may occur naturally over time.
stability_notes: Structure appears well built and perfectly stable.
revegetation_notes: No re-vegetation activities appeared to have occurred, and no salvaged plant material was observed throughout the site. For future projects, it is recommended that shrubs removed from the construction footprint be stockpiled and later placed on top of riprap with finer material to encourage re-vegetation, providing cover and food inputs.
cover_notes: Riprap boulders were placed intermittently throughout the stream channel, presumably to provide velocity breaks and potential cover through undercutting over time. However, there was currently very little cover within the entire bridge construction footprint. Future projects should incorporate vegetated riprap and re-vegetation efforts to enhance habitat quality.
maintenance_notes: No maintenance requirements at this time.
assessment_comments_og: Covert replaced with Bridge by C4 in the summer of 2024 with environmental oversight and engineering from DWB. Partial funding for the project was provided by FWCP through coordination from SERNbc. Very nicely designed structure that fits the stream channel well. Minimal rock placement within areas likely to be within the natural channel with not constricting the channel. Would recommend in the future that vegetated riprap be used, and that vegetation removed from the construction footprint. Be reinstalled within the construction footprint

dewatering_notes: Back water into the outlet pool has effectively worked matching deal the pool level with the outlet of the pipe this has caused flow throughout the structure where it is the water in sections, upstream, and downstream
velocity_notes: Although velocity of the tongue assessment was slow as flows were very low. It is expected that velocity exceed swim burst velocity of all species, including Chinook during high flows as the channel widths are up to three times or more wider upstream, indicating massive flows.
constriction_notes: Channell is majorly constricted as the concrete works to armor. The bottom of the pipe have constricted the structure further than 4 m to closer to 3 1/2 for the bottom third of the pipe.
substrate_notes:
It appears as though the 5 concrete baffles that were poured within the structure   Have been damaged by likely high flow events, and our not retaining very much substrate. There are five concrete baffles, and essentially only the second structure from upstream is retaining substrate

Although the water is in the outlet pool are turbid, it is expected that there is significant amounts of fines accumulated there due to the slow velocities
riparian_notes: Does not appear as though there was any riparian planting as part of the remediation works
flow_depth_notes: Depths of flow are very shallow however they are comparable to flow depths currently seen oxygen and downstream
stability_notes: The downstream back watering structures comprised of Newbury riffles appear to be stable and undamaged since 2019. The poured concrete and trouble boulder baffles, however, appear to have been damaged by high flow events since construction.
revegetation_notes: Although I’m verified, it does not appear as though there was any planting done as part of the project
cover_notes: The deep outlet pool is providing good Pool cover for Fish
maintenance_notes: The baffles within the structure need to be rebuilt to The most effective

dewatering_notes: Channell seems to be maturing well with beavers activity backing up extended sections, creating good Chinook, poor rearing habitat, even within the construction footprint
velocity_notes: Due to all the beaver activity velocities are slow with some riffle sections connecting back watered areas
constriction_notes: Channel within the riprap directly under the bridge is comparable and width to upstream and downstream
substrate_notes: Substrate appears appropriate for stream and comparable within the footprint to upstream and downstream. Primarily fines and gravel.
riparian_notes: Instead of beaver activity upstream has numerous filled Aspen trees and has no shrub planting to place as part of the construction there is minimal regrowth, except along the bottom margins of the rip wrap where natural Cottonwood growth is occurring along with dogwood and Willow
flow_depth_notes: What up, sir reasonable considering there are minimal flows at the time of assessment. There are very shallow riffle areas, but that is to be expected.
stability_notes: Structure is stable with no evidence of any
revegetation_notes: As the rock was not planted during installation is primarily Bear of any pro, and within the rest of the construction footprint is some volunteer Willow Cottonwood dogwood but still primarily revegetation grass is probably seated at time of construction. There’s some rose growth as well.
cover_notes: Cover has increased due to back watering from Beaverdam’s and large Woody debris due to dropping of trees by beavers
